item.title: A Beautiful City for Athena
item.dc:creator: Tracy Z
item.description: Athens, a city worshipped by people and gods. The beautiful capital of Greece is one of the oldest cities in the world. It is said to be the cradle of civilization and the birthplace of democracy. Named after the goddess of warfare and home to Plato’s Academy, this city gave rise to many wise men of [...]
item.content:encoded:
Athens, a city worshipped by people and gods. The beautiful capital of Greece is one of the oldest cities in the world. It is said to be the cradle of civilization and the birthplace of democracy. Named after the goddess of warfare and home to Plato’s Academy, this city gave rise to many wise men of ancient times.

My introduction to the magical city began at the Acropolis, where I was enchanted by the beautiful remains and the stunning Acropolis Museum. There I also learned about the city’s “catch, neuter, and release” program, which populated the streets with stray dogs. One of these free spirits, which I named Atticus because he found me and my friends at ‘the Roundabout of Atticus’ (or something by that name) and because I’ve always wanted to have a dog by that name after reading To Kill A Mockingbird, followed me & gang loyally from the Acropolis all the way to the Temple of Olympian Zeus, where we sadly parted ways when us humans headed for the subway.

Between visiting the Port of Piraeus and walking around Old Town Plaka, I also visited the Poet Sandal Maker who directed me to his favourite Greek restaurant nearby. After a satisfying feast there, I ended the day at the top of Lycabettus hill, overlooking the entire city. When the red and orange colours burned in the sky as the sun set over Athens, I remembered a great piece of advice I once heard: see the world as a traveller, not a tourist.


Filed under: Travel Diaries Tagged: Acropolis, Athena, Athens, culture, EU, Europe, Greece, lifestyle, ocean, paradise, Photography, photos, Piraeus, PostAWeek, PostAWeek2011, style, sunset, tourism, travel

item.title: A Bug By Any Other Name Is Still a Bomb
item.dc:creator: oldspouse
item.description: by Roger White It has been brought to my attention recently that I spend much time and space in this forum pining for yesterday. As one of my daughters’ buddies put it: “If you love the olden days so much, why don’t you marry them?” How does one respond to that? The only retort I [...]
item.content:encoded:
by Roger White

It has been brought to my attention recently that I spend much time and space in this forum pining for yesterday. As one of my daughters’ buddies put it: “If you love the olden days so much, why don’t you marry them?” How does one respond to that? The only retort I could conjure at the time was, “Oh, yeah?” (I think on my seat much better than on my feet, you see). Looking back, I realize I should have said, “Your face!” or something to that effect. Apparently, insults regarding one’s visage are the comeback du jour among the teen set.

The kid has a point, I guess. In my defense, however, I must emphasize that waxing nostalgic is a cherished rite of passage into geezerdom. Besides, what else am I going to pine for? Tomorrow? That’s just silly. And if there’s one thing I won’t tolerate in this column, it’s silliness! So there. Nyah.

Besides, it has always been this way. Surely, Joe Cro-Magnon sat around the cave in his declining years (which was probably about age 17) grunting on about the salad days of his youth.
“Ah, Neanderthal. Good times. Cave warmer. Women slower.”

“Ugh, Dad.”

“Don’t ‘ugh, dad’ me!”

Despite my yearning for all things moth-balled, outmoded and sepia-toned, I must confess that the yesterday of my memory likely glosses over events and places and conquests as they really were. The mind has a way of sanding down the warts.

Case in point: my recent Volkswagen adventure. Or as my wife terms it, the Great Bug Fiasco. It’s important to note that in the spring of my years, I drove, among other bombs, a VW, cherry red with a killer eight-track stereo and an exhaust system held on with coat hangers. I loved that little car like a boy loves his dog. And this thing smelled like one.

But, man, she was fun—when she was running. This is a crucial detail I conveniently fogged over as the years went by.

As I grew older, like so many other family men driving nondescript workaday sedans, I spent much of my adulthood wishing I still had my hippie wheels. Oh, if that old VW could talk, the tales she could tell—and the money I would make because I would have a talking car!

Anyway, one of my benign fantasies of late was searching for just the right Bug to bring back those carefree days. In my spare time, at home, at work, at lunch, at work, at the coffee shop, at work—mainly at work—I would browse web sites like ebay and various car-sales sites. It was purely a personal fiction; I knew I’d never actually go through with it. For one thing, we hadn’t the money nor the room for a third car, and swapping the trusty sedan (with all its airbags and terrific gas mileage and dependable brakes and styling like a refrigerator) for a 40-year-old antique wasn’t the most prudent move for a middle-income family with two teenage girls and two and a half mortgages. Thing two, I’m about as mechanical as a blind nun—and before all you seeing-impaired women of the cloth start besieging me with treatises on your intimate knowledge of carburetors and intake manifolds, it just sounded good, OK? Thing Three (and this is a big one, so I capitalized the Three), wifey would have absolutely none of it.

With all this in mind, sure enough I found just the right Bug. Oh, was she a sweetie. A 1979 Super Beetle convertible, with new silver paint and a new black cloth top, immaculate interior, working A/C (a VW rarity if there ever was one), and an engine, as far as I could tell. And to top it off, the seller lived in Taylor, just down the road a piece!

Against all odds and adult judgment, I began the beseeching process. Honey, the bug would actually be good on gas. Honey, I could teach the girls how to drive a stick. Honey, the motor on this thing is so simple, even I could fix it. Honey, pleeeeeeease!

Pretty embarrassing, all right. I think she gave in just to shut me up. We met the guy in a Wal-Mart parking lot east of town. I insisted on a thorough inspection and test drive, of course. I drove her once around the Wal-Mart parking lot and said I’d take it. So happy was I, I even named it: Herman the German.

I will say I did have a mechanic give Herman the once-over. He said, and I quote, “It seems to be functioning.”

That was good enough for me, so we sealed the deal at my credit union, where Mr. Bug Seller actually shed a few tears. It was then and there I should have remembered my Shakespeare: “The seller doth protest too much, methinks.” Hamlet wasn’t buying a Volkswagen, but you get the gist.

And you can guess the rest of the story. A week after my proud purchase, Herman began listing severely to the right every time I tapped the brakes. I began to fear the car would keel over on its side if I ever slammed on them too hard. Then one day, on the way home from work, Herman coughed like a cat with a five-pound furball and crapped out right there on the highway. One grim towing bill later, I was told by a mechanic that the engine’s fuel intake regulator had compression re-uptake over-valve flatulence or some such. Anyway, he said he fixed it.

He didn’t. A week after that, Herman died going to work. I dared to look: the engine was hissing and steaming and spewing black muck like an espresso machine. I didn’t know whether to call a mechanic or put a coffee mug under the motor. Mmm. Espresso.

The mechanic got him running again, but the romance was over. I sold Herman to a man from Dallas, and he had that same dreamy look I once had. He had his mechanic look Herman up and down, too, and his grease guy said the same thing mine did. The buyer called me the next week to say the motor konked out on the highway.

What can I tell ya, I said. You want nostalgia, buy a tie-dye t-shirt. It’s a hell of a lot cheaper.

Roger White is a freelance writer living in Austin, Texas, with his lovely wife, two precocious daughters, a very fat daschund, and a self-absorbed cat. For further adventures, visit oldspouse.wordpress.com.

item.title: 2/17/92 — Our NICU Journey Day 93
item.dc:creator: 2kop
item.description: Isaac — 1048 grams ↑ Molly — 1416 grams ↑   Isaac We are worried about your eyes. You have got Grade II-Grade III retinopathy of prematurity. We have to wait and see. More wait and see. I’m very upset about this. Molly You are three months old today, Molly, and overall you are doing [...]
item.content:encoded:
Isaac — 1048 grams ↑

Molly — 1416 grams ↑

 

Anyone familiar with premature infants will recognize these "preemie eyes" — big, bulging eyes in a still tiny face. But the real eye danger for preemies is not how they look, but a condition called retinopathy of prematurity (see Glossary Page) or ROP. After several weeks of delay, Ike and Molly both had eye checks on February 17. The news was not good. After three full months on the NICU and a couple of relatively stable weeks, I suddenly felt us plunging down another steep dip on the roller coaster. I don't know if you can tell by what I wrote that day, but I was devastated. Just when I had started to believe in a happy, healthy future, the words "blind" and "blindness" were being tossed around, and I felt totally blindsided. It was a horrible day. I sobbed for hours until, in one of his more brilliant partner interventions, Kenn kind of verbally slapped me by saying: "Relax. Blind is better than dead. One way or another, we'll figure it out." One of the many reasons I'm glad I'm not a single parent.

Isaac

We are worried about your eyes. You have got Grade II-Grade III retinopathy of prematurity. We have to wait and see. More wait and see. I’m very upset about this.

Molly

You are three months old today, Molly, and overall you are doing very well. You are growing and eating well. We got some distressing news about your eyes today, though. Your eye exam showed that you have retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). The blood vessels of your eyes have grown kinds of out of control and formed a ridge. There are four grades or levels of this disease. Level IV is complete detachment of the retina and that means blindness. You are at Level III+, poised kind of at the brink. If it stops now, it could regress and things could be fine. We have to wait and see.


Tagged: eye check, Isaac, ISCU (NICU), Molly, postaday2011, retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), twins, weight gain

item.title: Friday Roundtable: Does the “nostalgia factor” hinder our judgement when looking back at classic videogames?
item.dc:creator: Martin W.
item.description: We take off the rose-tinted glasses and try to put our retro cravings into perspective? Pop inside for our thoughts!
item.content:encoded:
If there’s one thing that we’ve realised this week at Bits ‘n’ Bytes with our incredibly popular (and fun) Retro Week, it’s the fact that videogames aren’t as young and as new as we sometimes think they are.  In reality, videogames are pretty old.  Over the course of this time, we’ve seen some pretty special games, which have not only entertained us, but have also revolutionised the world of videogames.

One of the most enjoyable aspects of Retro Week has been to take a look back at some excellent memories of our favourite videogames?. But has nostalgia got in the way of the Bits ‘n’ Bytes team?  Do gamers generally look back at games and remember them for being better than they actually are?  We put things into perspective in this week’s Friday Roundtable and ask ourselves whether the “nostalgia factor” is hindering our judgement.  Check out our thoughts below!

Martin Watts
Editor-in-Chief

As a gamer who is still very much into his retro, it’s very difficult for me to not be hindered by the “nostalgia factor”: I’m the weird guy who still thinks that the Nintendo 64 has cutting-edge graphics.  Nevertheless, I’ve gone back to old games that I love to play have realised that they’re pretty average or mediocre by today’s standards.  Back in the day, when you bought a game you had to appreciate it because they were usually very expensive and you didn’t tend to have a massive collection as a kid.  A great example of this would be Body Harvest for the Nintendo 64.  It didn’t exactly look great at the time, it controlled pretty badly and the story was cheesy good fun, but hardly an Oscar winner.  13 years later and it’s no better.  I still get great enjoyment from it though – retro games remind me of a time when I was really into my gaming (more so than even now) and I think this subconciously allows me to forgive the shortcomings.  At the same time though, I’m willing to admit that most people would find most of the games that I play either dated, terrible or both!

In short, I’ve been playing the likes of Goldeneye 007, Mario Kart 64, Perfect Dark and Mystical Ninja Starring Goemon 2 very frequently over the past decade or so.  Therefore, it’s not just the “nostalgia factor”, but also my inability to move on and try something new!

Armand Kossayan
North American Editor

Nostalgia colors my view of retro like the brush of a master painter. Seriously, if I’d never picked up an NES controller as a kid, and tried to play some of the classic games now with no nostalgia-tinted-lenses, I’d probably dump all over them.

Super Mario: All you do is run, jump, and maybe spit little red dots. You can’t even go backwards! Who thought that was a good idea!

MegaMan: Is this supposed to be impossible? Could Nintendo just give me a dunce hat instead and say I suck at video games?

Ninja Gaiden: That was the stupidest opening video ever. What the hell even happened. Two blobs jump at each other, than one gets smaller? Huh?

Instead, I think these games are brilliant and beautiful pieces of art, conveying deep emotion and creativity. Maybe they are, and maybe not, but either way, they have a special place in my heart. Modern games are so impressive, that to try to work backwards in gaming history, you would just perceive a drop in quality and content. Imagine playing Resident Evil 1 before Resident Evil 4. It would likely tear my mind in twain (yeah, I used twain, what are you gonna do about it!) and leave me frothing at the mouth in a seizure induced episode.

Some games I believe still do hold up. The Legend of Zelda for the SNES is a perfect example of a game made so well, and with such a timeless graphic style as to always be playable. A good chunk of the SNES library would make this cut, but for the most part, a lot of those games (brawlers) fail utterly by today’s standards. Perhaps I should be thankful to nostalgia for allowing me to continue to enjoy those games.

Michael Enger
PC Writer

I am absolutely stricken with nostalgiaitis, which manifests itself in the inability to objectively judge previous experiences if a few years has gone by, and with games it becomes even more obvious how this blurred remembrance affects me. I think back fondly on games that I played in my youth and seek out those same experiences only to be disappointed time and time again.

There is one game in particular which triggers the classic symptoms associated with this harrowing disorder. This game, which for the sake of my reputation shall remain nameless, but which is receiving a high-profile sequel in the coming months, is a game which I have attempted to complete at least a dozen times over, many years after its initial release. Every time it is mentioned I get that urge to play through it, thinking that this time it’ll be different, this time I’ll delve deep into the experience and come out the other side changed and somehow improved. And every time I am left with a foul taste in my mouth from the jerky gameplay, the inelegant AI and the unceremoniously bad scripted events. Somehow I don’t understand how we put up with something of this quality back when it first came out and why of all things do I hold this game in such esteem when I can’t get past the first mission without dying repeatedly due to some gameplay mechanic that has long since been ironed out of modern gaming?

I don’t think that the games I remember fondly have gotten any worse over the years, it is simply my accustomed taste to current games that change my experience with them. They are a snapshot of gaming trends and technological impairments, a rosetta stone of how gaming was a decade or two ago and stand to show just how much we have changed. From regenerating health and damage indicators to streamlined UIs and motion capture animation we have evolved past our humble beginnings as the experiences we had back then are lost to the tides of time, our evolving tastes and the refined experiences currently available to us showing us just how simplistic and limited our once-beloved games really were. One day Call of Duty: Black Ops will be considered retro and a whole generation of gamers will remember it fondly and perhaps dust off the discs once in a while to give the old knife-lundge another go only to discover that the gaming world has changed much since those days.

This doesn’t apply to good 2D games, though. They will be great forever.

Sebastian Force
PS3/Xbox 360 Writer

I recently went on a nostalgia kick, buying up every old game I could find that I used to love. While I still can’t find the bouncer, Play N Trade has managed to help me dig up a copy of Tekken Tag Tournament, Rayman 2: Revolution and a couple of others. Nostalgia will make us pay even slightly unnecessary amounts for things we used to have when we were children. I was going to pay $20 for a Bop-It. A Bop-It that I would never use, cause I’m 22 years old, but I wanted it so badly that I was willing to pay that much for it. Look at the prices online for Marvel VS Capcom. (The good one, not the second one that they already released) Look at everything Nintendo does that isn’t 3rd Party shovelware. Nostalgia is king at getting people to buy whatever items they need.

I’ve actually even used nostalgia to buy items that I knew were bad, but I had a good time with. Sonic the hedgehog, that horrible pro-furry remake was something I got as a gift when I was in college, and it was so bad that all I could do was laugh. Years later, I actually paid $5 for a copy of it again just so I could show my friends how bad it was, and later on vow to finish it. (Which will probably never happen.)

Nostalgia will make you buy a bad game again, and make you buy good games a fourth time.

Chad Morelock
PS3/PC Writer

In some cases, nostalgia definitely colors my experience with a game- particularly when it comes down to individual versions on different consoles (read: The Sega Genesis version is ALWAYS better!); however in all honesty I try not to let nostalgia effect me too much. In some cases, a game you loved as a kid have been terrible but you were too blind to see it (T&C Surf Designs), or it may not have aged well (Syphon Filter). In any case, the only real changes in viewpoint should come to graphics and sound- instead of great, they tend to be seen as “good for their time” if they HAVE aged well.

For example, I’d much rather boot up one of the early Command & Conquer games than get into one of the newer RTS’s. Sometimes you get a good degree of bloat from later generations of a game or genre (look at people’s biggest complaint about Final Fantasy VIII and most people will point to the overcomplicated Junction/Draw mechanic and lengthy tutorials), where earlier titles are easier to pick up and play. Long-winded, unskippable tutorials are one of my pet peeves in games, and it’s mostly a recent phenomenon.

I wouldn’t say nostalgia affects me much (other than getting murderous when someone insults the Genesis Sonic titles), because for as many great games that I played as a kid, there are a ton of terrible ones, and I recognized them as terrible then. Good games tend to stay good. Bad games are horrible for eternity.

Joe Walker
Wii/DS/Xbox 360 Writer

I definitely think that nostalgia affects how we remember games. My rose-tinted glasses have been broken many a time when I pop in a game I loved from my childhood and realize that it doesn’t make me feel the same way that it used to. There are several factors at work there, because I’m older so I don’t have the patience and “sense of wonder” that I had so much of as a kid. Games themselves have evolved over time as well, so as someone who’s been gaming constantly his whole life, even though I love retro games I find it harder to deal with things like clunky interfaces and artificial methods of boosting difficulty.

It may sound like I prefer newer games to older ones which isn’t true; I find it harder to get as excited for games now than I used to, mostly because much of what is being made these days is for a demographic that I’m simply not a part of. I still actively seek out classic gaming shops to buy games for my old systems and am a big fan of re-releases on Virtual Console and Xbox Live Arcade. I feel that old games will serve a similar purpose to old movies: they will remain as a sign of the times when they were made, and reflect values and production methods of the era. Also, of course, younger generations will never understand how we grew up playing them.

**

Do you suffer from bouts of nostalgia sickness?  Share your experiences below!

In some cases, nostalgia definitely colors my experience with a game- particularly when it comes down to individual versions on different consoles (read: The Sega Genesis version is ALWAYS better!); however in all honesty I try not to let nostalgia effect me too much. In some cases, a game you loved as a kid have been terrible but you were too blind to see it (T&C Surf Designs), or it may not have aged well (Syphon Filter). In any case, the only real changes in viewpoint should come to graphics and sound- instead of great, they tend to be seen as “good for their time” if they HAVE aged well.
For example, I’d much rather boot up one of the early Command & Conquer games than get into one of the newer RTS’s. Sometimes you get a good degree of bloat from later generations of a game or genre (look at people’s biggest complaint about Final Fantasy VIII and most people will point to the overcomplicated Junction/Draw mechanic and lengthy tutorials), where earlier titles are easier to pick up and play. Long-winded, unskippable tutorials are one of my pet peeves in games, and it’s mostly a recent phenomenon.
I wouldn’t say nostalgia affects me much (other than getting murderous when someone insults the Genesis Sonic titles), because for as many great games that I played as a kid, there are a ton of terrible ones, and I recognized them as terrible then. Good games tend to stay good. Bad games are horrible for eternity.

item.title: Frangipani – Jasmim – Plumeria in Brazil
item.dc:creator: oglesandobservations
item.description: “This one goes out to the one I love…..this one goes out to the one I left behind”. The first post I have ever dedicated to anyone, and this one goes out to my roommate from Atlanta who put up with my overly optimistic plant plans. It also goes out to my sweet husband, who [...]
item.content:encoded:
My vein attempt at a Frangipani in Georgia....for about ten years.....

“This one goes out to the one I love…..this one goes out to the one I left behind”.

The first post I have ever dedicated to anyone, and this one goes out to my roommate from Atlanta who put up with my overly optimistic plant plans. It also goes out to my sweet husband, who allowed me to tend to my plants wherever we lived and under whatever circumstances.

So I love plants, I love tropical plants. Orchids are my favorite, and right after them is a bush that I learned about first on a visit to Africa many years ago.  In Africa, the name of the bush is Frangipani; in America it is Plumeria. The bush, as I recalled it in Africa had the most beautiful white and yellow flowers, with a delicate aroma. Large, dark green leaves hosted a dozen or so blooms here and there.

Upon returning from the trip to Africa, I learned that the plant was known as Plumeria (previously, I had only known Plumeria to be a Bath & Bodyworks scent).  I had a friend bring me a plumeria plant back from a trip to Hawaii and I planted it.

I planted it in my roommate’s chic Midtown Atlanta condo. It was about 12 inches tall, a thick grey stick coming out of a pot.  Not very interesting, not very appealing, not very chic.

It sat there for a couple of years, indoors during the winter, out doors in summer.  Low and behold, it got to be about three feet tall then and (holding my breath) there was a bloom on it!

Thank you to my friend who put up with my plant plans!!

Then I moved Knoxville, TN, to get married, and took my then plant with me. The bloom never flowered….hope for the future.

I got married to my wonderful guy and we moved a couple more times, and my sweet husband always made sure I could bring my plant with me….sometimes coming with us in the back of the car, all seat-belted in.  Finally we ended up back in Atlanta, the place my plant always preferred most.  Three summers went by and finally my plant got to be about four feet tall, and another bloom came up but no flowering.

Then we moved to Brazil. The plant was too big to take to anyone’s home and definitely not going on the boat with our HHE, so I had to leave it behind.  It was so sad because you see, in winter my frangipani lost all its leaves and was back to its not-so-attractive dormant state of a grey stick or two coming out of the pot.  The picture above was it at its best, with a bloom on the horizon.

I confess…I cried when I had to leave my plant. I had it for almost 10 years!!!!

Jasmim tree in Joao Pessoa

So then we move to Brazil. We are riding along in what is spring time here (November), in a town called Joao Pessoa, and do you know what caught my eye?  A H-U-G-E frangipani bush!  Oh wow!  I was so thrilled! I pointed it out to my husband who, bless his heart, didn’t recognize what I was talking about because my plant never made it this far.

Same tree as above, just the whole thing....so big!

Finally, I was able to take a few shots of this particular bush/tree in Joao Pessoa….wow! So super happy!

Jasmim in Rosa (Frangipani in pink) at Pipa

Then when we went to Pipa, Brazil, I found the plant in PINK  as well!  Oh happy day!  Here it is known as Jasmim.

It’s sort of full circle to see my plant so big and happy here in Brazil, and so so pretty.  It brings back fond memories of my trip to visit my sister in Africa so long ago.

Thank you to my husband for tolerating my overly-optimistic view of plants! (Ironic, now that we live in the tropics, we have very few plants….)


Filed under: Family, Living in Brazil, Moving to Brazil, Nature, Uncategorized

item.title: My Single Greatest Tip for Achieving the Perfect State of Flow
item.dc:creator: Shawn Mihalik
item.description: Have you ever achieved that state of perfect flow? It’s that moment when, in the midst of doing something you love — like painting, drawing, running, anything really — the rest of the world fades into the background and the whole of your attention, all of your energy, is caught up in what you’re doing. [...]
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever achieved that state of perfect flow? It’s that moment when, in the midst of doing something you love — like painting, drawing, running, anything really — the rest of the world fades into the background and the whole of your attention, all of your energy, is caught up in what you’re doing. I’ve experienced this, and I’m sure you have, but not nearly as much as I’d like.

Until now, that is.

As an individual who puts a great deal of his focus into writing, both for profit and pleasure, I spend a lot of time in front of the computer, type type typing away as I compose a new blog post, poem or short story. A few days ago, I decided to remove the clock from my computer’s menu bar (I have a Mac), and nothing has been the same since.

Removing the clock from the menu bar, where it was constantly visible and in my line of sight, has made me realize how much of a slave I was to time. Before, I’d be working on a story only to look slightly up and to the right and realize that it’s nearly 2 AM and I should really go to bed. Now though, last night, in fact, I continued writing for as long as I wanted. There was no clock there to guilt me into sleeping. I was in a state of perfect flow, writing more than I ever have in a single sitting before, not stopping until I became aware that the sun was rising.

I urge you, turn off the clock every once and a while, especially where you work and where you play. If this means removing it from your computer’s task bar, then do so. If it requires turning of your cell phone, then turn it off. If it means taking that analogue clock off the wall and dropping it down the laundry chute, then just don’t mix up the laundry chute and the garbage chute because eventually you’ll have some appointment you’ll need to get to and knowing the time then will come in handy, but by all means, drop it down the laundry chute.

My clock now rests on my computer’s dashboard, where I can acces if I really need to with a simple press of F4. When I journal, which I do on paper, or when I read or paint or draw or run, I turn off my cell phone, and I mean I completely turn it off. Give it a shot. See how ignoring time every now and then improves your workflow and changes your perspective.

Time — what a flawed concept, huh?

item.title: Watch and Listen, or Read? Getting News in 2011
item.dc:creator: K.B.
item.description: I’ve admitted that I don’t know where I would be without the internet. It helps me keep in touch with friends, research new medications and treatments, and find information on everything from metric conversion for recipes, the hours of our local pharmacy, and the best way to clean a wood floor. We also use the [...]
item.content:encoded:
I’ve admitted that I don’t know where I would be without the internet. It helps me keep in touch with friends, research new medications and treatments, and find information on everything from metric conversion for recipes, the hours of our local pharmacy, and the best way to clean a wood floor.

We also use the internet for things that we used to find in the newspaper, such as movie listings and news, but by the time the newspaper goes to print, let alone landing in my driveway, it’s old news. Even phone books are outdated by the time these gargantuan tomes are dumped next to our mailbox.

This is where everyone used to go to get phone numbers.

I am still a believer in being able to feel the weight of what I am reading, in my hands, though am aware of the need to reduce our paper output. Obviously, I use the internet for almost all my info-gathering. But magazines, books, and Sudoku puzzles are much more fun when you are touching it. Although my hubby loves to read online – he loves his iPad – for leisure, for some things, nothing replaces paper.

Some things, like Sudoku, are better done on paper, so you can share with a friend.

The immediacy of the internet now satisfies our need for instant gratification. Half the news I encounter is delivered via video now. Are people too lazy to read their news anymore? Even on CNN.com, one of the biggest news sites in this country, produces more news via video than just an article. Sometimes, there is an article that accompanies the videos, but not always.

What happened to reading the news? When delivered via bodiless mouthpieces, I think it loses some of its objectivity. Talking heads can absolutely skew the angle of the story. And I haven’t mentioned that nearly video is preceding with an advertisement.

 

The same exact ad is also playing on the right side bar. (Screen Capture)

 

I was checking out the today’s news on CNN.com, and during my visit, wanted to look at five different headlines. None of the stories had a written article, so I had no choice but to passively watch the talking heads. Each news video was preceded by a 30-second commercial. Out of the five commercials, four were exactly the same.

Give the prisoner some variety, please.

If I have to watch advertisements every time I click on a headline, surely there are more than one or two commercials that can be shown to give the viewer some variety? It’s bad enough that I have to waste 30 seconds every time I click a headline, but to spend each half-minute watching the same advertisement, over and over, is not productive.

I guess it’s part of keeping the viewer on the page longer, and obviously, making money for every ad impression or click, but at what cost to the user experience? I’m to the point of abandoning videos once I see the commercial come on. Sure, they got their click, but I left the page in search of the same story elsewhere.

I understand that I probably will end up spending those some 30 seconds searching elsewhere for the same content, but the repetition and level frequency of commercials on a single news site is getting to be a poor user experience.

Is this part of the dumbing down of America? People who can’t read (or are too lazy) and need the news read to them? On top of that,, show the same commercials over and over to people for the brainwashing will take effect. Viewers will subconsciously help Audi to move 0.1% more inventory this month.

Here’s your two-part assignment.

1. Tell us if you would you  rather read your news or watch it.

2. How do you feel about commercials playing ads when clicking on a news video?

Share your thoughts!

item.title: Time to break out the running shoes
item.dc:creator: Becky Sue
item.description: We are experiencing two days of spring-like temps and it’s really invigorating. If you close your eyes (so you don’t see the 2-3′ of snow), breathe deep and absorb the sun you can almost believe that it’s spring. Especially if you listen to the water running through the gutters due to the snow melting. Melt, [...]
item.content:encoded:
We are experiencing two days of spring-like temps and it’s really invigorating. If you close your eyes (so you don’t see the 2-3′ of snow), breathe deep and absorb the sun you can almost believe that it’s spring. Especially if you listen to the water running through the gutters due to the snow melting. Melt, snow, MELT!

So yesterday I went for my first jog outside in 2 months. 3ish miles of taking my life into my hands due to snowbanks impeding on the road. And today I’m going to do it again but with a friend, who’s running the entire marathon!, and we’re going for 5ish miles. Tomorrow I’ll need a stretcher.

The training is on for the Vermont City Marathon on Memorial Day weekend. We found out last week that out of 1000 entrants our team was one of the lucky 700 chosen in the lottery. So, like last year, my husband and I will split the marathon by each running 13.1 miles. Also, like last year, we’ll be raising funds for animals in need.

I’m not a collector of things but I’m proud of my bibs. We’ll be adding a couple more this spring before the VCM in May. Running in these events is a huge motivator and incentive to keep in shape.

item.title: If you’re ever in a pickle and need a cat who can help(?), just call on Cat Cat!
item.dc:creator: notacrazycatlady
item.description: If you didn’t know, I have a twitter account (I still don’t really get it sometimes, but what they hey…it IS the 21st century after all.  I should be getting more involved with the Interwebs and all.) and my friend @blueda99 shared with me a fun tweet from @badbanana regarding, what else?  Cats. And [...]
item.content:encoded:
The soon to be villain/hero(?)

If you didn’t know, I have a twitter account (I still don’t really get it sometimes, but what they hey…it IS the 21st century after all.  I should be getting more involved with the Interwebs and all.) and my friend @blueda99 shared with me a fun tweet from @badbanana regarding, what else?  Cats.

And it goes….ahem….

“Catwoman is so played out. Here’s my suggestion for the next Batman movie. Catcat. A cat with slightly enhanced cat powers.”

So here you have it, my version of Cat Cat.  This cat is impressive with his enhanced cat powers, which will send him to the next box office blockbuster.  He can move fast but only if he wants to, especially when it becomes an annoyance.  BAM!  He can sleep a lot!  POW!  He can shed fur a lot!  ZAM!  He can meow a lot!  SOCK!  He can digest a lot!  SLIPPER!

So, Mr. Siedell, I hope we can collaborate and make this project happen.  I’ll go in halfsies with you.  Have your people call me people.  Except after 9 because I’ll already be asleep probably.

item.title: Graphic: Anger rages through Middle East and North Africa
item.dc:creator: National Post Staff
item.description: The Middle East and North Africa convulsed with protests again on Wednesday. From Benghazi to Bahrain, a new generation clashed with government forces, demanding more freedom and an end to autocratic control.
item.content:encoded: The Middle East and North Africa convulsed with protests again on Wednesday. From Benghazi to Bahrain, a new generation clashed with government forces, demanding more freedom and an end to autocratic control.
